Through  the  proposed  Micro,  Small,  and  Medium  Enterprise 
Development  Project  (the  Project),  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB)  will  reinforce  the  efforts  of  the  Government  of  India  (the 
Government) to assist these enterprises, which have tremendous 
employment- and income-generating potential, in coping with and 
recovering from the adverse effects of the ongoing global financial 
crisis.  The  reduction  in  credit,  stagnation  in  domestic  demand, 
sharp  decline  in  exports,  and  overall  crisis  of  confidence  that 
followed  the  global  crisis  have  added  to  the  burden  faced  by 
micro,  small,  and  medium  enterprises  (MSMEs)  in  the  form  of 
long-standing  systemic  constraints.  These 
limited 
institutional  credit,  high-cost  borrowing,  weak  marketing  facilities, 
poor infrastructure, technological obsolescence, and a perception 
that  they  are  high-risk  enterprises.  This  sector  is  the  second-
largest  employer  after  agriculture,  and  the  Government  has 
therefore  taken  steps  to  enhance  credit  flows  to  it.  The  various 
other  fiscal  and  monetary  stimulus  measures  taken  by  the 
Government—such  as  increasing  public  spending,  offering  tax 
cuts,  and  lowering  various  bank  policy  rates—are  also  indirectly 
designed  to  support  the  MSME  sector.  The  Government  has 
asked  the  Small  Industries  Development  Bank  of  India  (SIDBI) 
and  the  commercial  banks  to  increase  their  lending  to  the 
MSMEs.  It  has  also  been  actively  mobilizing  additional  external 
funding.

The  JFPR-financed  CBG,  currently  under  consideration  by  the

The  combined  results  of  the  various  elements  under  the  Project

The impact of the proposed intervention will be to help MSMEs in 
India  realizing  their  full  potential,  thereby  assisting  domestic 
MSMEs  to  be  fully  developed,  especially  those  led  by  female 
microentrepreneurs.  
 
The  outcome  of  the  Project  is  improved  MSME  access  to 
commercial  financing,  capacity  building  services  and  market 
opportunities,  thereby  fostering  MSME  growth,  competitiveness, 
and employment. 
 
The  Project  is  designed  to  achieve  its  objectives  through  a 
multipronged approach that will address key bottlenecks to MSME 
financing  and  development  in  India  by  focusing  on  (i)  helping 
commercial public sector banks gain better access to longer-term 
financing for onlending to their MSME clients in selected states (to 
be agreed with ADB) of India by setting up a PCG facility of up to 
$250  million  without  a  government  counterindemnity;  and  (ii) 
supporting  the  so-called  “missing  middle”  borrower  segment  of 
microenterprises  through  an  ADB  loan  of  $50 million  from  ADB’s 
ordinary  capital  resources  (OCR),  which  will  provide  dollar

The  proposed  PCG  facility  of  up  to  $250  million,  without

The  PCG  facility  will  be  made  available  to  one  or  more 
participating  banks  comprised  of  the  large  commercial  public 
sector  banks  in  India,  and  will  cover  a  portion  of  principal  and/or 
interest payments on a US dollar or other major foreign currency 
denominated  loan  made  to  or  bond  issued  by  one  or  more 
participating banks and sold to investors.  
 
SIDBI will be the Borrower and the Executing Agency (EA) of the 
ADB  loan  of  $50  million  to  be  funded  from  ADB’s  OCR.  The 
proposed loan will have a 15-year term including a grace period of 
3  years,  an  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
London  interbank  offered  rate-based  lending  facility,  and  a 
commitment  fee  of  0.15  per  annum  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The Government 
will provide a guarantee to ADB in respect of the proposed loan.  
 
Each  PCG  will  cover  less  than  100%  of  principal  and  interest  of 
the underlying debt instrument1 with a tenor of 5 years (maximum 
10  years,  on  a  strictly  exceptional  basis).  In  accordance  with 
ADB's exposure policy,2 the maximum amount of each underlying 
debt  instrument  will  be  the  lower  of  $250  million  and  50%  of  the 
net worth of the relevant participating bank. It is expected that the 
guaranteed  debt  instrument  will  be  denominated  in  US  dollars. 
However,  the  ADB  guaranteed  debt  instrument  can  also  be 
denominated  in  Japanese  yen  or  euros,  in  which  case  the  PCG 
will be denominated in the same currency as the underlying debt 
instrument. The participating banks will use the proceeds from the 
ADB-guaranteed  debt  instrument  to  increase  their  commercially-
priced loan portfolio with their MSME clients.  
 
The loan proceeds will be lent directly to SIDBI in dollars and for a 
15-year term pursuant to a loan agreement with such other terms 
and conditions acceptable to ADB. The Government will provide a 
guarantee to ADB in respect of the proposed loan and will charge 
SIDBI  an  appropriate  guarantee  fee.  Onlending  by  SIDBI  to 
eligible  subborrowers  will  be  at  interest  rates  that  reflect  SIDBI’s 
cost  of  funds  plus  a  spread  to  cover  transaction  costs  and  risks. 
Subloans will be on full commercial and competitive terms.

The  following  criteria  will  be  used  to  determine  the  eligibility  of 
commercial  public  sector  banks  for  participation  in  the  PCG 
facility:  (i)  an  international  credit  rating  of  minimum  BB+  or  a 
domestic  rating  of  AA  if  the  participating  bank  does  not  have  an 
international rating; (ii) experience and outreach in the delivery of 
financial  services  to  MSME  clients;  (iii)  focused  marketing  plans 
and capacity to develop new MSME products using the proceeds 
from  the  ADB-enhanced  instrument;  (iv)  loan  origination  and 
administration  capacities,  skills,  and  standards;  (v)  overall 
financial  standing  as  determined  according  to  ADB’s  internal 
guidelines;  and  (vi)  a  net  nonperforming  loan  ratio  of  not  more 
than 3% for its MSME portfolio.

will  carry  out  a  thorough  due  diligence  of  each  interested  bank.

(i)  Macroeconomic  risk.  A  slower-than-expected  recovery 
from the current global financial crisis could dampen growth 
prospects  in  India.  However,  current  projections  for  India 
indicate  a  relatively  high  average  growth  of  6%,  and  7%  in 
2010,  as  the  global  economy  begins  to  emerge  from  this

(ii)  Credit  risk.  MSMEs  typically  carry  higher  credit  risk  due  to 
the lack of accurate and reliable financial information on their 
performance, underdeveloped management capabilities and 
governance  structure,  as  well  as  greater  vulnerabilities  to 
downside  market  factors.  The  program  aims  to  focus  on 
PFIs  and  participating  banks  that  have  a  robust  risk 
management infrastructure and established risk assessment 
methodologies  that  are  specifically  tailored  to  the  MSME 
sector,  and  which  have  a  demonstrated  track  record  in 
MSME  lending.  Detailed  due  diligence  will  cover  the  banks' 
operations in general but will also include an assessment of 
the  PFIs  and  participating  banks'  performance  in  its  MSME 
portfolio  which  will  cover  asset  quality,  provisioning

Poverty  reduction  and  social  development  through  faster  and  more  inclusive  growth  is

and medium enterprise (MSME) sector in India has immense potential to generate such broad-

The  promotion  and  development  of  the  MSME  sector  in  India  is  a  key  component  in

facilitating  increased  credit  flow  to  MSMEs  under  various  priority  sector  lending  programs. 
Under these policies, banks are required to ensure that a defined percentage (currently 40%) of 
their  overall  lending  is  targeted  to  priority  sectors,  as  classified  by  the  Government  (priority 
sectors include agriculture, small industries, and exports).  
 
13. 
Several  committees  have  been  constituted  to  increase  the  credit  flow  to  MSMEs.  The 
Nayak  Committee  (FY1991–FY1992)  set  up  by  RBI  dealt  with  aspects  of  adequacy  and 
timeliness of credit to MSMEs. The Committee estimated that MSMEs were obtaining working 
capital  to  the  extent  of  8.1%  (FY2005  and  FY2006)  of  the  sector’s  annual  output,  which  was 
less than the standard requirement of 20%, and recommended the MSME sector should obtain 
20%  of  its  annual  projected  turnover  by  way  of  working  capital. 6  The  Ganguly  Committee 
(FY2004) emphasized the need for new vehicles and instruments such as credit intermediaries 
dedicated  to  MSME  and  trade  financing.  Such  credit  intermediaries  would  be  designed  to 
absorb credit risk and serve as instruments for extending quick credit to the clusters accredited 
to MSMEs (including export clusters).7

Both  public  and  private  sector  banks  have  started  to  adopt  a  combination  of  “cluster

Microfinance Institutions 

 
19. 
In  the  last  20  years  finance  has  also  been  supplied—especially  to  the  smallest 
MSMEs—through  specialized  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs).  This  effort  has  been  led  by  the 
SIDBI Foundation for Microcredit (SFMC), SIDBI, and other apex lending institutions, including 
the National Credit Fund for Women (Rashtriya Mahila Kosh), which are responsible for much of 
the growth of the sector. SFMC and SIDBI are the largest players, and introduced a number of 
innovations,  including  mainstreaming  the  microfinance  sector,  facilitating  links  to  commercial 
banks  and  lenders,  promoting  better  practices  among  MFIs  through  its  capacity  building 
program, and pioneering support to rating initiatives and new instruments (including the recently 
launched transformation loan and quasi-equity product). These initiatives have helped the MFI 
sector grow rapidly over the last few years, but with a few exceptions, most of the initiatives are 
small  and  region-specific,  and  have  limited  collective  outreach.  Some  MFIs  are  based  on  the 
Grameen model. Others promote and establish financial links with self-help groups (SHGs). The 
MFIs offer some of the features of the informal sector—such as flexible products and customer-
friendly  practices—but  at  higher  interest  rates  than  the  formal  sector,  while  introducing  some 
features of formal institutions, such as documented loan contracts, detailed books of accounts, 
management  information  systems,  staff,  and  some  degree  of  supervision  by  a  regulatory 
authority.

42. 
The impact of the proposed Project is to help MSMEs in India realize their full potential, 
thereby  assisting  domestic  MSMEs  in  India,  in  conjunction  with  the  JFPR-financed  CBG, 
currently under consideration by the GOJ, to be fully developed, particularly those led by female 
microentrepreneurs.  The  specific  and  immediate  expected  outcome  of  the  Project  is  improved 
MSME  access  to  commercial  financing,  capacity  building  services  and  market  opportunities, 
thereby fostering MSME growth, competitiveness, and employment creation. 
 
43. 
The  objective  of  the  proposed  Project  is  to  improve  MSME  access  to  finance  and 
business  development  services,  thereby  fostering  MSME  growth,  competitiveness,  and 
employment  creation,  which  are  key  to  achieving  the  Government's  overall  objectives  of 
inclusive  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  The  Project  is  designed  to  achieve  this 
objective through a multipronged approach that will address key bottlenecks to MSME financing 
and development in India by focusing on: (i) helping commercial public sector banks, which are 
the  main  credit  providers  to  the  MSME  sector  in  India,  gain  better  access  to  longer-term 
financing  for  lending  to  MSMEs  in  the  country;  (ii)  providing  financing  (through  SIDBI)  to  the 
"missing middle" borrower segment, composed of microfinance borrowers that have grown too 
large for financial support from MFIs, but remain unable to access bank financing because they 
are (a) still considered  not creditworthy, and (b) operate primarily in the informal sector; and (iii) 
strengthening  capacity  building  and  BDS  and  market  linkage  programs  for  microenterprises 
primarily led by women entrepreneurs, thereby improving their profitability, competitiveness, and 
creditworthiness.

Overview 

 
The Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) was established in April 1990

enterprises (i.e., so-called “medium enterprises”).

In coordination with the risk management committee, the risk management department

monitoring, and restructuring of accounts. Although the basic tenets of SIDBI’s loan policy have 
been in place for several years—and follow “know your customer” norms issued by the RBI—
management has recently sought to align its strategy, organizational structure, and processes in

the  expanded  mandate  to  service medium-sized  enterprises.  To  this end,  the  credit  appraisal,

i.

39. 
SIDBI  uses  standard  loan  application  forms  in  an  effort  to  better  and  more  efficiently 
assess the risks of a potential borrower. For loan applications up to Rs20 million ($400,000) for 
existing MSME clients (and service sector projects, banks, nonbanking financial companies and 
infrastructure  projects),  the  appraisal  and  credit  rating  is  carried  out  using  the  credit  analysis 
and  rating  tool  (CART).  This  in-house  system  guides  the  credit  officer  through  an  integrated 
computer-based process of appraisal and credit rating of the proposed loan. These models are 
effective  tools  that  are  used  to  streamline  and  simplify  the  credit  risk  review  process,  thereby 
enabling a risk-based management system.

default. These two ratings are then combined to provide a final rating, which is displayed in the 
form of a risk grade. There are eight risk grades (CR1 to CR8), with CR1 being the top grade. 
RAM  is  installed  on  SIDBI’s  central  server  at  the  offices  in  Mumbai;  being  web-based,  it  is 
accessible to all its field offices.

1. 

Capital Adequacy 

 
SIDBI reported a capital adequacy ratio (CAR) of 43.16% in FY2006, 37.48% in FY2007, 
53. 
and  41.75%  as  of  the  end  of  FY2008.  The  slight  deterioration  from  the  2006  level  can  be 
attributed to the global financial turmoil and the weak financial health of SFCs. Nevertheless, the 
capital adequacy ratio is strong, reflecting demonstrated support from the Government and the 
subsequent  strong  resource  profile.  It  reflects  SIDBI’s  ability  to  (i)  maintain  asset  quality  in  its 
direct financing portfolio during the overall economic slowdown, (ii) minimize losses despite its 
significant exposure to financially weak SFCs, and (iii) access low-cost resources. 
 

2. 

Asset Quality 

 
54. 
Total assets have fluctuated in recent years, largely in response to changes in the loan 
portfolio, investment securities, and bank balances, but remain strong despite SIDBI's exposure 
to  weakly  performing  SFCs  and  SIDCs.  Although  SIDBI  did  not  have  asset-quality  protection 
mechanisms, such as credit guarantee funds, enjoyed by other institutions such as the National 
Bank  for  Agriculture  and  Rural  Development,  or  the  state government  guarantees  available  to 
the Power Finance Corporation, it was able to maintain strong asset quality. SIDBI has shifted 
its  focus  to  direct  financing  of  MSMEs,  which  includes  schemes  for  lending  to  projects  in  the 
MSME sector, bills discounting, and financing of infrastructure projects.  
 
55. 
In  FY2008,  the  gross  NPA  ratio  was  1.48%,  net  NPA  ratio  0.25%,  substandard  assets 
ratio 0.12%, and doubtful assets ratio 0.13%. Exposure to all SFC NPAs has been fully written 
off.  During  FY2008,  NPAs  increased  by  Rs4.69  billion  mainly  due  to  the  exposure  of  Rs3.71 
billion  to  Uttar  Pradesh  Financial  Corporation  that  turned  a  loss.  Overall,  the  financial  market 
downturn  pressured  both  the  SFCs  and  micro  and  small  businesses  to  maintain  profitability. 
This  could  in  turn  impact  the  future  ability  of  SIDBI  to  maintain  the  asset  quality  of  its  direct 
financing portfolio.

Unlike commercial banks, SIDBI is not allowed to take direct deposits to fund its lending

the  World  Bank  (Rs4.6  billion  credit  line  in  FY2008),  the  Japan  Bank  for  International 
Cooperation  (Rs10.6  billion  in  FY2008),  German  development  assistance  through  KfW  (Rs5.2 
billion  in  FY2008),  and  the  International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development  (Rs0.9  billion  in 
FY2008). These deposits, along with the capital gains bonds, form the bulk of SIDBI’s resources 
and enable it to significantly reduce its cost of borrowings.

I.          POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  

 
Despite  recent  rapid  economic  growth,  poverty  in  India  is  widespread,  and  the  nation  is  estimated  to  have  one  of  the 
largest concentrations of poor people in the world, totaling a third of the world's poor. According to the criterion used by the 
Planning Commission of India, 27.5% of the population (or nearly 302 million people) were living below the poverty line in 
2004–2005, down from  51.3% in 1977–1978, and  36% in 1993–1994, a reduction of  less than 1% per  year.a About 221 
million  people  (72%  of  the  poor)  live  in  rural  areas  and  most  depend  on  subsistence  farming  for  their  livelihood.  The 
majority (59%) of the poor are small landholders, marginal farmers, and landless labors; two thirds of agricultural laborers 
are  women.  Rural  poverty  was  28.3%  and  urban  poverty  was  25.7%  in  2004–2005.  An  estimated  34.3%  of  the  people 
lived on less than $1/day in 2004–2005, with 80.4% of people living on less than $2/day.b. According to the World Bank's 
new  estimates  based  on  purchasing  power  parity  exchange  rates  and  domestic  prices  for  2005,  42%  of  the  population 
lived on less than $1.25/day in 2005 compared with 49.9% in 1993–1994. The new estimate also shows that 75.6% people 
lived  on  less  than  $2/day  in  2005.c  Poverty  in  India  is  partly  attributed  to  the  overconcentration  of  the  workforce  in  the 
agriculture sector, with corresponding low productivity. In 2007, about 56% of the total population depended on agriculture, 
while  agriculture  contributed  18%  to  the  gross  national  product.  It  is  anticipated  that  the  slowdown  in  growth  will  impact 
poverty. The proposed Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprise Development Project (the Project) is in line with the priorities 
set  out  by  the  Government  of  India  (the  Government)  in  its  11th  Five-Year  Plan  with  respect  to  the  micro,  small,  and 
medium  enterprise  (MSME)  sector  and,  more  specifically,  to  the  importance  assigned  to  support  for  women’s 
empowerment in the Prime Minister’s 15-point program, and in other flagship schemes of the Government.d 
 
Support  for  inclusive  growth  and  the  catalyzing  of  investment  through  innovative  financing  modalities  has  been  a  critical 
element in all of India's five year plans, including the ongoing 11th FYP. India's five year plans also emphasize the need to 
promote  the  financial  sector,  develop  micro,  small,  and  medium  enterprises  (MSME),  and  support  gender  equity  issues 
and concerns. With respect to MSME development, it is stated that (i) the provision of information, markets, technology, 
and business development services should include mechanisms to promote participation by women and their enterprises; 
and (ii) gender-based barriers to accessing finance should be analyzed and addressed.f The proposed Project will support 
access by MSMEs to term-finance and capacity-development services. The capacity building grant (CBG), currently under 
consideration by the Government of Japan (GOJ), will complement the proposed approach under the Project by providing 
much-needed  capacity  development  support  to  low-income  microentrepreneurs—most  of  whom  are  women—in  the 
informal  sector.  The  CBG,  currently  under  consideration  by  the  GOJ,  will  therefore  respond  to  the  commitment  to  a 
gender-inclusive  financial  sector  and  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  development  by  engaging  with  the  Small 
Industries  Development  Bank  of  India  (SIDBI)  and  its  partner  microfinance  institutions  in  further  advancing  their 
commitment to the pro-poor, social and gender-inclusive focus of their operations while also addressing the specific needs 
and constraints faced by low-income women entrepreneurs.

1.  Key Issues  
 
The MSME sector touches on the lives of many of the most vulnerable in society, including minorities, women, scheduled 
castes,  and  scheduled  tribes  in  villages,  urban  slums,  and  pockets  of  poverty  in  flourishing  towns  and  cities.  For  many 
families, it is the only source of livelihood, while for others, it supplements family income. Women are mostly found in the 
unregistered  sector—food  processing  enterprises,  manufacturing  enterprises,  and  weaving—and  often  work  part  time  in 
the family enterprises. Women’s enterprises are micro- and small-scale enterprises managed by one or more women as a

collateral.  Some  of  the  MSMEs  also  fall  outside  the  reach  of  microfinance  schemes,  and  are  thus  compelled  to  depend

II.          SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
 
The  debate  on  provision  of  financial  services  to  poor  and  low-income  households  in  India  has  revolved  around  the  rural 
population since India’s banks were first nationalized. Unlike rural financial intermediation, the flow of financial resources to 
urban  populations  was  never  seriously  debated  in  India.  The  tendency  among  microfinance  intermediaries  to  move 
towards  urban  centers  arose  only  after  rural  markets  were  saturated.  The  self-help  group-bank  linkage  model  remains 
predominantly  a  rural  phenomena,  however.  The  first  targeted  credit  program  with  a  focus  on  enterprise  and  self-
employment  opportunities  in  urban  areas  was  launched  in  1989  during  the  7th  Five-Year  Plan  period  (1985–1990).  The 
various urban poverty alleviation schemes with a credit focus introduced in India since 1989 have broadly followed a top-
down approach.g The flow of credit from formal financial institutions to urban population groups increased steadily in India 
since the 1970s, and this has come to be concentrated in large cities and upper credit brackets. Although social banking 
efforts  undertaken  by  the  central  bank  and  the  Government’s  financial  intermediation  in  rural  areas  have  undergone  an 
expansion  phase,  the  overall  expansion  in  financial  intermediation  has  largely  bypassed  low-income,  asset-holding 
populations in urban areas.  While the state’s poverty  alleviation approach has steadily  expanded from mere provision of 
basic amenities and services to facilitating creation of income-earning opportunities, it has failed to significantly impact the 
urban poor.
